verses.text: Would therefore, O my beloved, that as the word requires, we might here so govern ourselves at all times and entirely, and so live, as never to forget the noble acts of God, nor to depart from the practice of virtue! As also the Apostolic voice exhorts; 'Remember Jesus Christ, that He rose from the dead.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:50
verses.text: ' Not that any limited season of remembrance was appointed, for at all times He should be in our thoughts.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:51
verses.text: But because of the slothfulness of many, we delay from day to day.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:52
verses.text: Let us then begin in these days.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:53
verses.text: To this end a time of remembrance is permitted, that it may show forth to the saints the reward of their calling, and may exhort the careless while reproving them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:54
verses.text: Therefore in all the remaining days, let us persevere in virtuous conduct, repenting as is our duty, of all that we have neglected, whatever it may be; for there is no one free from defilement, though his course may have been but one hour on the earth, as Job, that man of surpassing fortitude, testifies.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:55
verses.text: But, 'stretching forth to those things that are to come,' let us pray that we may not eat the Passover unworthily, lest we be exposed to dangers.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:56
verses.text: For to those who keep the feast in purity, the Passover is heavenly food; but to those who observe it profanely and contemptuously, it is a danger and reproach.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:57
verses.text: For it is written, 'Whosoever shall eat and drink unworthily, is guilty of the death of our Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:58
verses.text: ' Wherefore, let us not merely proceed to perform the festal rites, but let us be prepared to draw near to the divine Lamb, and to touch heavenly food.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:59
verses.text: Let us cleanse our hands, let us purify the body.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:60
verses.text: Let us keep our whole mind from guile; not giving up ourselves to excess, and to lusts, but occupying ourselves entirely with our Lord, and with divine doctrines; so that, being altogether pure, we may be able to partake of the Word.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:61
verses.text: We begin the holy fast on the fourteenth of Pharmuthi (Apr.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:62
verses.text: ), on the [first] evening of the week; and having ceased on the nineteenth of the same month Pharmuthi (Apr.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:63
verses.text: ), the first day of the holy week dawns upon us on the twentieth of the same month Pharmuthi (Apr.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:64
verses.text: ), to which we join the seven weeks of Pentecost; with prayers, and fellowship with our neighbour, and love towards one another, and that peaceable will which is above all.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:65
verses.text: For so shall we be heirs of the kingdom of heaven, through our Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom to the Father be glory and dominion for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:66
verses.text: All the brethren who are with me salute you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:67
verses.text: Salute one another with a holy kiss.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 5:68
verses.text: Here endeth the fifth Festal Letter of holy Athanasius.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:1
verses.text: Letter VI.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:2
verses.text: —For.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:3
verses.text: Easter-day, xii Pharmuthi, vii Id.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:4
verses.text: April; xvii Moon; aera Dioclet.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:5
verses.text: ; Coss.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:6
verses.text: Optatus Patricius, Anicius Paulinus; Praefect, Philagrius, the Cappadocian; vii Indict.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:7
verses.text: Now again, my beloved, has God brought us to the season of the feast, and through His loving-kindness we have reached the period of assembly for it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:8
verses.text: For that God who brought Israel out of Egypt, even He at this time calls us to the feast, saying by Moses, 'Observe the month of new fruits, and keep the Passover to the Lord thy God:' and by the prophet, 'Keep thy feasts, O Judah; pay to the Lord thy vows.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:9
verses.text: ' If then God Himself loves the feast, and calls us to it, it is not right, my brethren, that it should be delayed, or observed carelessly; but with alacrity and zeal we should come to it, so that having begun joyfully here, we may also receive an earnest of that heavenly feast.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:10
verses.text: For if we diligently celebrate the feast here, we shall doubtless receive the perfect joy which is in heaven, as the Lord says; 'With desire I have desired to eat this Passover with you before I suffer.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:11
verses.text: For I say unto you, that I will not eat it, until it is fulfilled with you in the kingdom of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:12
verses.text: ' Now we eat it if, understanding the reason of the feast, and acknowledging the Deliverer, we conduct ourselves in accordance with His grace, as Paul saith; 'So that we may keep the Feast, not with old leaven, neither with the leaven of wickedness; but with the unleavened bread of sincerity and truth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:13
verses.text: ' For the Lord died in those days, that we should no longer do the deeds of death.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:14
verses.text: He gave His life, that we might preserve our own from the snares of the devil.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:15
verses.text: And, what is most wonderful, the Word became flesh, that we should no longer live in the flesh, but in spirit should worship God, who is Spirit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:16
verses.text: He who is not so disposed, abuses the days, and does not keep the feast, but like an unthankful person finds fault with the grace, and honours the days overmuch, while he does not supplicate the Lord who in those days redeemed him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:17
verses.text: Let him by all means hear, though fancying that he keeps the feast, the Apostolic voice reproving him; 'Ye observe days, and months, and times, and years: I fear lest I have laboured among you in vain.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:19
verses.text: For the feast is not on account of the days; but for the Lord's sake, who then suffered for us, we celebrate it, for 'our Passover Christ, is sacrificed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:20
verses.text: ' Even as Moses, when teaching Israel not to consider the feast as pertaining to the days, but to the Lord, said, 'It is the Lord's Passover.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:21
verses.text: ' To the Jews, when they thought they were keeping the Passover, because they persecuted the Lord, the feast was useless; since it no longer bore the name of the Lord, even according to their own testimony.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:22
verses.text: It was not the Passover of the Lord, but that of the Jews.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:23
verses.text: The Passover was named after the Jews, my brethren, because they denied the Lord of the Passover.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:24
verses.text: On this account, the Lord, turning away His face from such a doctrine of theirs, saith, 'Your new moons and your sabbaths My soul hateth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:26
verses.text: So now, those who keep the Passover in like manner, the Lord again reproves, as He did those lepers who were cleansed, when He loved the one as thankful, but was angry with the others as ungrateful, because they did not acknowledge their Deliverer, but thought more of the cure of the leprosy than of Him who healed them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:27
verses.text: 'But one of them when he saw that he was healed, turned back, and with a loud voice glorified God, and fell on his face at the feet of Jesus giving Him thanks; and he was a Samaritan.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:28
verses.text: And Jesus answering said, Were there not ten cleansed? but those nine—whence are there none found who returned to give glory to God, but this stranger?' And there was more given to him than to the rest; for being cleansed from his leprosy, he heard from the Lord, 'Arise, go thy way, thy faith hath saved thee.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:29
verses.text: ' For he who gives thanks, and he who glorifies, have kindred feelings, in that they bless their Helper for the benefits they have received.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:30
verses.text: So the Apostle exhorts all men to this, saying, 'Glorify God with your body;' and the prophet commands, saying, 'Give glory to God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:31
verses.text: ' Although testimony was borne by Caiaphas against our Redeemer, and He was set at nought by the Jews, and was condemned by Pilate in those days, yet exalted exceedingly and most mighty was the voice of the Father which came to Him; 'I have glorified, and will glorify again.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:32
verses.text: ' For those things which He suffered for our sake have passed away; but those which belong to Him as the Saviour remain for ever.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:33
verses.text: But in our commemoration of these things, my brethren, let us not be occupied with meats, but let us glorify the Lord, let us become fools for Him who died for us, even as Paul said; 'For if we are foolish, it is to God; or if we are sober-minded, it is to you; since because one died for all men, therefore all were dead to Him; and He died for all, that we who live should not henceforth live to ourselves, but to Him who died for us, and rose again.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:34
verses.text: ' No longer then ought we to live to ourselves, but, as servants to the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:35
verses.text: And not in vain should we receive the grace, as the time is especially an acceptable one, and the day of salvation hath dawned, even the death of our Redeemer.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:36
verses.text: For even for our sakes the Word came down, and being incorruptible, put on a corruptible body for the salvation of all of us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:37
verses.text: Of which Paul was confident, saying, 'This corruptible must put on incorruption.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:38
verses.text: ' The Lord too was sacrificed, that by His blood He might abolish death.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:39
verses.text: Full well did He once, in a certain place, blame those who participated vainly in the shedding of His blood, while they did not delight themselves in the flesh of the Word, saying, 'What profit is there in my blood, that I go down to corruption?' This does not mean that the descent of the Lord was without profit, for it gained the whole world; but rather that after He had thus suffered, sinners would prefer to suffer loss than to profit by it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:40
verses.text: For He regarded our salvation as a delight and a peculiar gain; while on the contrary He looked upon our destruction as loss.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:41
verses.text: Also in the Gospel, He praises those who increased the grace twofold, both him who made ten talents of five, and him who made four talents of two, as those who had profited, and turned them to good account; but him who hid the talent He cast out as wanting, saying to him, 'Thou wicked servant! oughtest thou not to have put My money to the exchangers? then at My coming I should have received Mine own with interest.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:42
verses.text: Take, therefore, from him the talent, and give it to him that hath ten talents.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:43
verses.text: For to every one that hath shall be given, and he shall have more abundantly; but from him that hath not, shall be taken away even that which he hath.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:44
verses.text: And cast ye the unprofitable servant into outer darkness; there shall be weeping and gnashing of teeth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:45
verses.text: ' For it is not His will that the grace we have received should be unprofitable; but He requires us to take pains to render Him His own fruits, as the blessed Paul saith; 'The fruit of the Spirit is love, joy, and peace.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:46
verses.text: ' Having therefore this right resolution, and owing no man anything, but rather giving everything to every man, he was a teacher of the like rightness of principle, saying, 'Render to all their dues.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:47
verses.text: ' He was like those sent by the householder to receive the fruits of the vineyard from the husbandmen; for he exhorted all men to render a return.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:48
verses.text: But Israel despised and would not render, for their will was not right, nay moreover they killed those that were sent, and not even before the Lord of the vineyard were they ashamed, but even He was slain by them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:49
verses.text: Verily, when He came and found no fruit in them, He cursed them through the fig-tree, saying, 'Let there be henceforth no fruit from thee;' and the fig-tree was dead and fruitless so that even the disciples wondered when it withered away.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:50
verses.text: Then was fulfilled that which was spoken by the prophet; 'I will take away from them the voice of joy and the voice of gladness, the voice of the bridegroom and the voice of the bride, the scent of myrrh, and the light of a lamp, and the whole land shall be destroyed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:51
verses.text: ' For the whole service of the law has been abolished from them, and henceforth and for ever they remain without a feast.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:52
verses.text: And they observe not the Passover; for how can they? They have no abiding place, but they wander everywhere.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:53
verses.text: And they eat unleavened bread contrary to the law, since they are unable first to sacrifice the lamb, as they were commanded to do when eating unleavened bread.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:54
verses.text: But in every place they transgress the law, and as the judgments of God require, they keep days of grief instead of gladness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:55
verses.text: Now the cause of this to them was the slaying of the Lord, and that they did not reverence the Only-Begotten.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:56
verses.text: At this time the altogether wicked heretics and ignorant schismatics are in the same case; the one in that they slay the Word, the other in that they rend the coat.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:57
verses.text: They too remain expelled from the feast, because they live without godliness and knowledge, and emulate the conduct shewn in the matter of Bar-Abbas the robber, whom the Jews desired instead of the Saviour.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:58
verses.text: Therefore the Lord cursed them under the figure of the fig-tree.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:59
verses.text: Yet even thus He spared them in His loving-kindness, not destroying them root and all.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:60
verses.text: For He did not curse the root, but [said], that no man should eat fruit of it thenceforth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:61
verses.text: When He did this, He abolished the shadow, causing it to wither; but preserved the root, so that we might [not] be grafted upon it; 'they too, if they abide not in unbelief, may attain to be grafted into their own olive tree.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:62
verses.text: ' Now when the Lord had cursed them because of their negligence, He removed from them the new moons, the true lamb, and that which is truly the Passover.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:63
verses.text: But to us it came: there came too the solemn day, in which we ought to call to the feast with a trumpet, and separate ourselves to the Lord with thanksgiving, considering it as our own festival.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:64
verses.text: For we are bound to celebrate it, not to ourselves but to the Lord; and to rejoice, not in ourselves but in the Lord, who bore our griefs and said, 'My soul is sorrowful unto death.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:65
verses.text: ' For the heathen, and all those who are strangers to our faith, keep feasts according to their own wills, and have no peace, since they commit evil against God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:66
verses.text: But the saints, as they live to the Lord also keep the feast to Him, saying, 'I will rejoice in Thy salvation,' and, 'my soul shall be joyful in the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:67
verses.text: ' The commandment is common to them, 'Rejoice, ye righteous, in the Lord'—so that they also may be gathered together, to sing that common and festal Psalm, 'Come, let us rejoice,' not in ourselves, but, 'in the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:69
verses.text: For thus the patriarch Abraham rejoiced not to see his own day, but that of the Lord; and thus looking forward 'he saw it, and was glad.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:70
verses.text: ' And when he was tried, by faith he offered up Isaac, and sacrificed his only-begotten son—he who had received the promises.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:71
verses.text: And, in offering his son, he worshipped the Son of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:72
verses.text: And, being restrained from sacrificing Isaac, he saw the Messiah in the ram, which was offered up instead as a sacrifice to God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:73
verses.text: The patriarch was tried, through Isaac, not however that he was sacrificed, but He who was pointed out in Isaiah; 'He shall be led as a lamb to the slaughter, and as a sheep before her shearers he shall be speechless;' but He took away the sin of the world.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:74
verses.text: And on this account [Abraham] was restrained from laying his hand on the lad, lest the Jews, taking occasion from the sacrifice of Isaac, should reject the prophetic declarations concerning our Saviour, even all of them, but more especially those uttered by the Psalmist; 'Sacrifice and offering Thou wouldest not; a body Thou hast prepared Me;' and should refer all such things as these to the son of Abraham.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:75
verses.text: For the sacrifice was not properly the setting to rights of Isaac, but of Abraham who also offered, and by that was tried.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:76
verses.text: Thus God accepted the will of the offerer, but prevented that which was offered from being sacrificed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:77
verses.text: For the death of Isaac did not procure freedom to the world, but that of our Saviour alone, by whose stripes we all are healed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:78
verses.text: For He raised up the falling, healed the sick, satisfied those who were hungry, and filled the poor, and, what is more wonderful, raised us all from the dead; having abolished death, He has brought us from affliction and sighing to the rest and gladness of this feast, a joy which reacheth even to heaven.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:79
verses.text: For not we alone are affected by this, but because of it, even the heavens rejoice with us, and the whole church of the firstborn, written in heaven, is made glad together, as the prophet proclaims, saying, 'Rejoice, ye heavens, for the Lord hath had mercy upon Israel.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:80
verses.text: Shout, ye foundations of the earth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:81
verses.text: Cry out with joy, ye mountains, ye high places, and all the trees which are in them, for the Lord hath redeemed Jacob, and Israel hath been glorified.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:82
verses.text: ' And again; 'Rejoice, and be glad, ye heavens; let the hills melt into gladness, for the Lord hath had mercy on His people, and comforted the oppressed of the people.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:84
verses.text: The whole creation keeps a feast, my brethren, and everything that hath breath praises the Lord, as the Psalmist [says], on account of the destruction of the enemies, and our salvation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:85
verses.text: And justly indeed; for if there is joy in heaven over one sinner that repenteth, what should there not be over the abolition of sin, and the resurrection of the dead? Oh what a feast and how great the gladness in heaven! how must all its hosts joy and exult, as they rejoice and watch in our assemblies, those that are held continually, and especially those at Easter? For they look on sinners while they repent; on those who have turned away their faces, when they become converted; on those who formerly persisted in lusts and excess, but who now humble themselves by fastings and temperance; and, finally, on the enemy who lies weakened, lifeless, bound hand and foot, so that we may mock at him; 'Where is thy victory, O Death? where is thy sting, O Grave?' Let us then sing unto the Lord a song of victory.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:86
verses.text: Who then will lead us to such a company of angels as this? Who, coming with a desire for the heavenly feast, and the angelic holiday, will say like the prophet, 'I will pass to the place of the wondrous tabernacle, unto the house of God; with the voice of joy and praise, with the shouting of those who keep festival?' To this course the saints also encourage us, saying, 'Come, let us go up to the mountain of the Lord, and to the house of the God of Jacob.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:87
verses.text: ' But not for the impure is this feast, nor is the ascent thereto for sinners; but it is for the virtuous and diligent; and for those who live according to the aim of the saints; for, 'Who shall ascend to the hill of the Lord? or who shall stand in His holy place, but he that hath clean hands, and a pure heart; who hath not devoted his soul to vanity, nor sworn deceitfully to his neighbour.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:88
verses.text: For he,' as the Psalmist adds, when he goes up, 'shall receive a blessing from the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:89
verses.text: ' Now this clearly also refers to what the Lord gives to them at the right hand, saying, 'Come, ye blessed, inherit the kingdom prepared for you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:90
verses.text: ' But the deceitful, and he that is not pure of heart, and possesses nothing that is pure (as the Proverb saith, 'To a deceitful man there is nothing good'), shall assuredly, being a stranger, and of a different race from the saints, be accounted unworthy to eat the Passover, for 'a foreigner shall not eat of it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:91
verses.text: ' Thus Judas, when he thought he kept the Passover, because he plotted deceit against the Saviour, was estranged from the city which is above, and from the apostolic company.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:92
verses.text: For the law commanded the Passover to be eaten with due observance; but he, while eating it, was sifted of the devil, who had entered his soul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:93
verses.text: Wherefore let us not celebrate the feast after an earthly manner, but as keeping festival in heaven with the angels.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:94
verses.text: Let us glorify the Lord, by chastity, by righteousness, and other virtues.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:95
verses.text: And let us rejoice, not in ourselves, but in the Lord, that we may be inheritors with the saints.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:96
verses.text: Let us keep the feast then, as Moses.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:97
verses.text: Let us watch like David who rose seven times, and in the middle of the night gave thanks for the righteous judgments of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:98
verses.text: Let us be early, as he said, 'In the morning I will stand before Thee, and Thou wilt look upon me: in the morning Thou wilt hear my voice.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:99
verses.text: ' Let us fast like Daniel; let us pray without ceasing, as Paul commanded; all of us recognising the season of prayer, but especially those who are honourably married; so that having borne witness to these things, and thus having kept the feast, we may be able to enter into the joy of Christ in the kingdom of heaven.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:100
verses.text: But as Israel, when going up to Jerusalem, was first purified in the wilderness, being trained to forget the customs of Egypt, the Word by this typifying to us the holy fast of forty days, let us first be purified and freed from defilement, so that when we depart hence, having been careful of fasting, we may be able to ascend to the upper chamber with the Lord, to sup with Him; and may be partakers of the joy which is in heaven.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:101
verses.text: In no other manner is it possible to go up to Jerusalem, and to eat the Passover, except by observing the fast of forty days.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:102
verses.text: We begin the fast of forty days on the first day of the month Phamenoth (Feb.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:103
verses.text: ); and having prolonged it till the fifth of Pharmuthi (Mar.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:104
verses.text: ), suspending it upon the Sundays and the Saturdays preceding them, we then begin again on the holy days of Easter, on the sixth of Pharmuthi (Apr, ), and cease on the eleventh of the same month (Apr.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:105
verses.text: ), late in the evening of the Saturday, whence dawns on us the holy Sunday, on the twelfth of Pharmuthi (Apr.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:106
verses.text: ), which extends its beams, with unobscured grace, to all the seven weeks of the holy Pentecost.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:107
verses.text: Resting on that day, let us ever keep Easter joy in Christ Jesus our Lord, through Whom, to the Father, be glory and dominion for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:108
verses.text: All the brethren who are with me salute you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:109
verses.text: Salute one another with a holy kiss.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 6:110
verses.text: Here endeth the sixth Festal Letter of the holy and God-clad Athanasius.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:1
verses.text: Letter VII.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:2
verses.text: —For.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:3
verses.text: Easter-day iv Pharmuthi, iii Kal.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:4
verses.text: April; xx Moon; aer.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:5
verses.text: Dioclet.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:6
verses.text: ; Coss.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:7
verses.text: Julius Constantius, the brother of Augustus, Rufinus Albinus; Praefect, the same Philagrius; viii Indict.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:8
verses.text: The blessed Paul wrote to the Corinthians that he always bore in his body the dying of Jesus, not as though he alone should make that boast, but also they and we too, and in this let us be followers of him, my brethren.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:9
verses.text: And let this be the customary boast of all of us at all times.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:10
verses.text: In this David participated, saying in the Psalms, 'For thy sake we die all the day; we are accounted as sheep for the slaughter.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:11
verses.text: ' Now this is becoming in us, especially in the days of the feast, when a commemoration of the death of our Saviour is held.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:12
verses.text: For he who is made like Him in His death, is also diligent in virtuous practices, having mortified his members which are upon the earth, and crucifying the flesh with the affections and lusts, he lives in the Spirit, and is conformed to the Spirit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:13
verses.text: He is always mindful of God, and forgets Him not, and never does the deeds of death.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:14
verses.text: Now, in order that we may bear in our body the dying of Jesus, he immediately adds the way of such fellowship, saying, 'we having the same spirit of faith, as it is written, I believed, and therefore have I spoken; we also believe, and therefore speak.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:15
verses.text: ' He adds also, speaking of the grace that arises from knowledge; 'For He that raised up Jesus, will also raise us up with Jesus, and will present us before Him with you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:17
verses.text: When by such faith and knowledge the saints have embraced this true life, they receive, doubtless, the joy which is in heaven; for which the wicked not caring, are deservedly deprived of the blessedness arising from it.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:18
verses.text: For, 'let the wicked be taken away, so that he shall not see the glory of the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:19
verses.text: ' For although, when they shall hear the universal proclamation of the promise, 'Awake, thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead,' they shall rise and shall come even to heaven, knocking and saying, 'Open to us;' nevertheless the Lord will reprove them, as those who put the knowledge of Himself far from them, saying, 'I know you not.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:20
verses.text: ' But the holy Spirit cries against them, 'The wicked shall be turned into hell, even all the nations that forget God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:21
verses.text: ' Now we say that the wicked are dead, but not in an ascetic life opposed to sin; nor do they, like the saints, bear about dying in their bodies.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:22
verses.text: But it is the soul which they bury in sins and follies, drawing near to the dead, and satisfying it with dead nourishment; like young eagles which, from high places, fly upon the carcases of the dead, and which the law prohibited, commanding figuratively, 'Thou shalt not eat the eagle, nor any other bird that feedeth on a dead carcase;' and it pronounced unclean whatsoever eateth the dead.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:23
verses.text: But these kill the soul with lusts, and say nothing but, 'let us eat and drink, for to morrow we die.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:24
verses.text: ' And the kind of fruit those have who thus love pleasures, he immediately describes, adding, 'And these things are revealed in the ears of the Lord of Hosts, that this sin shall not be forgiven you until ye die.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:25
verses.text: ' Yea, even while they live they shall be ashamed, because they consider their belly their lord; and when dead, they shall be tormented, because they have made a boast of such a death.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:26
verses.text: To this effect also Paul bears witness, saying, 'Meats for the belly, and the belly for meats; but God shall destroy both it and them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:27
verses.text: ' And the divine word declared before concerning them; 'The death of sinners is evil, and those who hate the righteous commit sin.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:28
verses.text: ' For bitter is the worm, and grievous the darkness, which wicked men inherit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:29
verses.text: But the saints, and they who truly practise virtue, 'mortify their members which are upon the earth, fornication, uncleanness passions, evil concupiscence;' and, as the result of this, are pure and without spot, confiding in the promise of our Saviour, who said, 'Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:30
verses.text: ' These, having become dead to the world, and renounced the merchandise of the world, gain an honourable death; for, 'precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of His saints.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:31
verses.text: ' They are also able, preserving the Apostolic likeness, to say, 'I am crucified with Christ, nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:32
verses.text: ' For that is the true life, which a man lives in Christ; for although they are dead to the world, yet they dwell as it were in heaven, minding those things which are above, as he who was a lover of such a habitation said, 'While we walk on earth, our dwelling is in heaven.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:33
verses.text: ' Now those who thus live, and are partakers in such virtue, are alone able to give glory to God, and this it is which essentially constitutes a feast and a holiday.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:34
verses.text: For the feast does not consist in pleasant intercourse at meals, nor splendour of clothing, nor days of leisure, but in the acknowledgment of God, and the offering of thanksgiving and of praise to Him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:35
verses.text: Now this belongs to the saints alone, who live in Christ; for it is written, 'The dead shall not praise Thee, O Lord, neither all those who go down into silence; but we who live will bless the Lord, from henceforth even for ever.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:36
verses.text: ' So was it with Hezekiah, who was delivered from death, and therefore praised God, saying, 'Those who are in hades cannot praise Thee; the dead cannot bless Thee; but the living shall bless Thee, as I also do.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:37
verses.text: ' For to praise and bless God belongs to those only who live in Christ, and by means of this they go up to the feast; for the Passover is not of the Gentiles, nor of those who are yet Jews in the flesh; but of those who acknowledge the truth in Christ, as he declares who was sent to proclaim such a feast; 'Our Passover, Christ, is sacrificed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:39
verses.text: Therefore, although wicked men press forward to keep the feast, and as at a feast praise God, and intrude into the Church of the saints, yet God expostulates, saying to the sinner, 'Why dost thou talk of My ordinances?' And the gentle Spirit rebukes them, saying, 'Praise is not comely in the mouth of a sinner.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:40
verses.text: ' Neither hath sin any place in common with the praise of God; for the sinner has a mouth speaking perverse things, as the Proverb saith, 'The mouth of the wicked answereth evil things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:41
verses.text: ' For how is it possible for us to praise God with an impure mouth? since things which are contrary to each other cannot coexist.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:42
verses.text: For what communion has righteousness with iniquity? or, what fellowship is there between light and darkness? So exclaims Paul, a minister of the Gospel.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:43
verses.text: Thus it is that sinners, and all those who are aliens from the Catholic Church, heretics, and schismatics, since they are excluded from glorifying (God) with the saints, cannot properly even continue observers of the feast.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:44
verses.text: But the righteous man, although he appears dying to the world, uses boldness of speech, saying, 'I shall not die, but live, and narrate all Thy marvelous deeds.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:45
verses.text: ' For even God is not ashamed to be called the God of those who truly mortify their members which are upon the earth, but live in Christ; for He is the God of the living, not of the dead.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:46
verses.text: And He by His living Word quickeneth all men, and gives Him to be food and life to the saints; as the Lord declares, 'I am the bread of life.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:47
verses.text: ' The Jews, because they were weak in perception, and had not exercised the senses of the soul in virtue, and did not comprehend this discourse about bread, murmured against Him, because He said, 'I am the bread which came down from heaven, and giveth life unto men.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:49
verses.text: For sin has her own special bread, of her death, and calling to those who are lovers of pleasure and lack understanding, she saith, 'Touch with delight secret bread, and sweet waters which are stolen;' for he who merely touches them knows not that that which is born from the earth perishes with her.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:50
verses.text: For even when the sinner thinks to find pleasure, the end of that food is not pleasant, as the Wisdom of God saith again, 'Bread of deceit is pleasant to a man; but afterwards his mouth shall be filled with gravel.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:51
verses.text: ' And, 'Honey droppeth from the lips of a whorish woman, which for a time is sweet to thy palate; but at the last thou shalt find it more bitter than gall, and sharper than a two-edged sword.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:52
verses.text: ' Thus then he eats and rejoices for a little time; afterwards he spurneth it when he hath removed his soul afar.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:53
verses.text: For the fool knoweth not that those who depart far from God shall perish.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:54
verses.text: And besides, there is the restraint of the prophetic admonition which says, 'What hast thou to do in the way of Egypt, to drink the waters of Gihon? And what hast thou to do in the way of Asshur, to drink the waters of the rivers?' And the Wisdom of God which loves mankind forbids these things, crying, 'But depart quickly, tarry not in the place, neither fix thine eye upon it; for thus thou shalt pass over strange waters, and depart quickly from the strange river.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:55
verses.text: ' She also calls them to herself, 'For wisdom hath builded her house, and supported it on seven pillars; she hath killed her sacrifices, and mingled her wine in the goblets, and prepared her table; she hath sent forth her servants, inviting to the goblet with a loud proclamation, and saying, Whoso is foolish, let him turn in to me; and to them that lack understanding she saith, Come, eat of my bread, and drink of the wine I have mingled for you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:56
verses.text: ' And what hope is there instead of these things? 'Forsake folly that ye may live, and seek understanding that ye may abide.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:57
verses.text: ' For the bread of Wisdom is living fruit, as the Lord said; 'I am the living bread which came down from heaven: if any man eat of this bread, he shall live for ever.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:58
verses.text: ' For when Israel ate of the manna, which was indeed pleasant and wonderful, yet he died, and he who ate it did not in consequence live for ever, but all that multitude died in the wilderness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:59
verses.text: The Lord teaches, saying, 'I am the bread of life: your fathers did eat manna in the wilderness, and are dead.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:60
verses.text: This is the bread which came down from heaven, that a man should eat thereof, and not die.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:62
verses.text: Now wicked men hunger for bread like this, for effeminate souls will hunger; but the righteous alone, being prepared, shall be satisfied, saying, 'I shall behold Thy face in righteousness; I shall be satisfied when Thy glory is seen by me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:63
verses.text: ' For he who partakes of divine bread always hungers with desire; and he who thus hungers has a never-failing gift, as Wisdom promises, saying, 'The Lord will not slay the righteous soul with famine.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:64
verses.text: ' He promises too in the Psalms, 'I will abundantly bless her provision; I will satisfy her poor with bread.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:65
verses.text: ' We may also hear our Saviour saying, 'Blessed are they who hunger and thirst after righteousness, for they shall be filled.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:66
verses.text: ' Well then do the saints and those who love the life which is in Christ raise themselves to a longing after this food.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:67
verses.text: And one earnestly implores, saying, 'As the hart panteth after the fountains of waters, so panteth my soul after Thee, O God! My soul thirsteth for the living God, when shall I come and see the face of God?' And another; 'My God, my God, I seek Thee early; my soul thirsteth for Thee; often does my flesh, in a dry and pathless land, and without water.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:68
verses.text: So did I appear before Thee in holiness to see Thy power and Thy glory.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:70
verses.text: Since these things are so, my brethren, let us mortify our members which are on the earth, and be nourished with living bread, by faith and love to God, knowing that without faith it is impossible to be partakers of such bread as this.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:71
verses.text: For our Saviour, when He called all men to him, and said, 'If any man thirst, let him [come] to Me and drink,' immediately spoke of the faith without which a man cannot receive such food; 'He that believeth on Me, as the Scripture saith, out of his belly shall flow rivers of living water.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:72
verses.text: ' To this end He continually nourished His believing disciples with His words, and gave them life by the nearness of His divinity, but to the Canaanitish woman, because she was not yet a believer, He deigned not even a reply, although she stood greatly in need of food from Him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:73
verses.text: He did this not from scorn, far from it (for the Lord is loving to men and good, and on that account He went into the coasts of Tyre and Sidon); but because of her unbelief, and because she was of those who had not the word.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:74
verses.text: And He did it righteously, my brethren; for there would have been nothing gained by her offering her supplication before believing, but by her faith she would support her petition; 'For He that cometh to God, must first believe that He is, and that He is a rewarder of them that seek Him;' and that 'without faith it is impossible for a man to please Him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:75
verses.text: ' This Paul teaches.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:76
verses.text: Now that she was hitherto an unbeliever, one of the profane, He shews, saying, 'It is not meet to take the children's bread, and to cast it to dogs.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:77
verses.text: ' She then, being convinced by the power of the word, and having changed her ways, also gained faith; for the Lord no longer spoke to her as a dog, but conversed with her as a human being, saying, 'O woman, great is thy faith!' As therefore she believed, He forthwith granted to her the fruit of faith, and said, 'Be it to thee as thou desirest.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:78
verses.text: And her daughter was healed in the self-same hour.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:80
verses.text: For the righteous man, being nurtured in faith and knowledge, and the observance of divine precepts, has his soul always in health.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:81
verses.text: Wherefore it is commanded to 'receive to ourselves him who is weak in the faith,' and to nourish him, even if he is not yet able to eat bread, but herbs, 'for he that is weak eateth herbs.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:82
verses.text: ' For even the Corinthians were not able to partake of such bread, being yet babes, and like babes they drank milk.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:83
verses.text: 'For every one that partaketh of milk is unskilful in the word of righteousness,' according to the words of that divine man.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:84
verses.text: The Apostle exhorts his beloved son Timothy, in his first Epistle, 'to be nourished with the word of faith, and the good doctrine whereto he had attained.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:85
verses.text: ' And in the second, 'Preserve thou the form of sound words which thou hast heard of me, in faith and love which are in Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:86
verses.text: ' And not only here, my brethren, is this bread the food of the righteous, neither are the saints on earth alone nourished by such bread and such blood; but we also eat them in heaven, for the Lord is the food even of the exalted spirits, and the angels, and He is the joy of all the heavenly host.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:87
verses.text: And to all He is everything, and He has pity upon all according to His loving-kindness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:88
verses.text: Already hath the Lord given us angels' food, and He promises to those who continue with Him in His trials, saying, 'And I promise to you a kingdom, as My Father hath promised to Me; that ye shall eat and drink at My table in My kingdom, and sit on twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:89
verses.text: ' O what a banquet is this, my brethren, and how great is the harmony and gladness of those who eat at this heavenly table! For they delight themselves not with that food which is cast out, but with that which produces life everlasting.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:90
verses.text: Who then shall be deemed worthy of that assembly? Who is so blessed as to be called, and accounted worthy of that divine feast? Truly, 'blessed is he who shall eat bread in Thy kingdom.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:92
verses.text: Now he who has been counted worthy of the heavenly calling, and by this calling has been sanctified, if he grow negligent in it, although washed becomes defiled: 'counting the blood of the covenant by which he was sanctified a profane thing, and despising the Spirit of grace,' he hears the words, 'Friend, how camest thou in hither, not having wedding garments?' For the banquet of the saints is spotless and pure; 'for many are called, but few chosen.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:93
verses.text: ' Judas to wit, though he came to the supper, because he despised it went out from the presence of the Lord, and having abandoned his Life, hanged himself.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:94
verses.text: But the disciples who continued with the Redeemer shared in the happiness of the feast.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:95
verses.text: And that young man who went into a far country, and there wasted his substance, living in dissipation, if he receive a desire for this divine feast, and, coming to himself, shall say, 'How many hired servants of my father have bread to spare, while I perish here with hunger!' and shall next arise and come to his father, and confess to him, saying, 'I have sinned against heaven and before thee, and am not worthy to be called thy son; make me as one of thy hired servants;'—when he shall thus confess, then he shall be counted worthy of more than he prayed for.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:96
verses.text: For the father does not receive him as a hired servant, neither does he look upon him as a stranger, but he kisses him as a son, he brings him back to life as from the dead, and counts him worthy of the divine feast, and gives him his former and precious robe.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:97
verses.text: So that, on this account, there is singing and gladness in the paternal home.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:98
verses.text: For this is the work of the Father's loving-kindness and goodness, that not only should He make him alive from the dead, but that He should render His grace illustrious through the Spirit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:99
verses.text: Therefore, instead of corruption, He clothes him with an incorruptible garment; instead of hunger, He kills the fatted calf; instead of far journeys, [the Father] watched for his return, providing shoes for his feet; and, what is most wonderful, placed a divine signet-ring upon his hand; whilst by all these things He begot him afresh in the image of the glory of Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:100
verses.text: These are the gracious gifts of the Father, by which the Lord honours and nourishes those who abide with Him, and also those who return to Him and repent.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:101
verses.text: For He promises, saying, 'I am the bread of life; he that cometh unto Me shall not hunger, and he that believeth on Me shall never thirst.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:102
verses.text: ' We too shall be counted worthy of these things, if at all times we cleave to our Saviour, and if we are pure, not only in these six days of Easter, but consider the whole course of our life as a feast, and continue near and do not go far off, saying to Him, 'Thou hast the words of eternal life, and whither shall we go?' Let those of us who are far off return, confessing our iniquities, and having nothing against any man, but by the spirit mortifying the deeds of the body.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:103
verses.text: For thus, having first nourished the soul here, we shall partake with angels at that heavenly and spiritual table; not knocking and being repulsed like those five foolish virgins, but entering with the Lord, like those who were wise and loved the bridegroom; and shewing the dying of Jesus in our bodies, we shall receive life and the kingdom from Him.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:104
verses.text: We begin the fast of forty days on the twenty-third of Mechir (Feb.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:105
verses.text: ), and the holy fast of the blessed feast on the twenty-eighth of Phamenoth (Mar.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:106
verses.text: ); and having joined to these six days after them, in fastings and watchings, as each one is able, let us rest on the third of the month Pharmuthi (Mar.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:107
verses.text: ), on the evening of the seventh day.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:108
verses.text: Also that day which is holy and blessed in everything, which possesses the name of Christ, namely the Lord's day, having risen upon us on the fourth of Pharmuthi (Mar.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:109
verses.text: ), let us afterwards keep the holy feast of Pentecost.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:110
verses.text: Let us at all times worship the Father in Christ, through Whom to Him and with Him be glory and dominion by the Holy Ghost for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:111
verses.text: All the brethren who are with me salute you: salute one another with a holy kiss.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:112
verses.text: There is no eighth or ninth, for he did not send them, for the reason before mentioned.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 7:113
verses.text: Here endeth the seventh Festal Letter of holy Athanasius the Patriarch.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:1
verses.text: Letter X.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:2
verses.text: —For.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:3
verses.text: Coss.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:4
verses.text: Ursus and Polemius; Praef.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:5
verses.text: the same Theodorus, of Heliopolis, and of the Catholics.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:6
verses.text: After him, forthe second year, Philagrius; Indict.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:7
verses.text: xi; Easter-day, vii Kal.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:8
verses.text: Ap.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:9
verses.text: xxx Phamenoth; Moon ½; aera Dioclet.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:10
verses.text: Although I have travelled all this distance from you, my brethren, I have not forgotten the custom which obtains among you, which has been delivered to us by the fathers, so as to be silent without notifying to you the time of the annual holy feast, and the day for its celebration.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:11
verses.text: For although I have been hindered by those afflictions of which you have doubtless heard, and severe trials have been laid upon me, and a great distance has separated us; while the enemies of the truth have followed our tracks, laying snares to discover a letter from us, so that by their accusations, they might add to the pain of our wounds; yet the Lord, strengthening and comforting us in our afflictions, we have not feared, even when held fast in the midst of such machinations and conspiracies, to indicate and make known to you our saving Easter-feast, even from the ends of the earth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:12
verses.text: Also when I wrote to the presbyters of Alexandria, I urged that these letters might be sent to you through their instrumentality, although I knew the fear imposed on them by the adversaries.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:13
verses.text: Still, I exhorted them to be mindful of the apostolic boldness of speech, and to say, 'Nothing separates us from the love of Christ; neither affliction, nor distress, nor persecution, nor famine, nor nakedness, nor peril, nor sword.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:14
verses.text: ' Thus, keeping the feast myself, I was desirous that you also, my beloved, should keep it; and being conscious that an announcement like this is due from me, I have not delayed to discharge this duty, fearing to be condemned by the Apostolic counsel; 'Render to every man his due.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:16
verses.text: While I then committed all my affairs to God, I was anxious to celebrate the feast with you, not taking into account the distance between us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:17
verses.text: For although place separate us, yet the Lord the Giver of the feast, and Who is Himself our feast, Who is also the Bestower of the Spirit, brings us together in mind, in harmony, and in the bond of peace.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:18
verses.text: For when we mind and think the same things, and offer up the same prayers on behalf of each other, no place can separate us, but the Lord gathers and unites us together.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:19
verses.text: For if He promises, that 'when two or three are gathered together in His name, He is in the midst of them,' it is plain that being in the midst of those who in every place are gathered together, He unites them, and receives the prayers of all of them, as if they were near, and listens to all of them, as they cry out the same Amen.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:20
verses.text: I have borne affliction like this, and all those trials which I mentioned, my brethren, when I wrote to you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:21
verses.text: And that we may not distress you at all, I would now (only) briefly remind you of these things, because it is not becoming in a man to forget, when more at ease, the pains he experienced in tribulation; lest, like an unthankful and forgetful person, he should be excluded from the divine assembly.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:22
verses.text: For at no time should a man freely praise God, more than when he has passed through afflictions; nor, again, should he at any time give thanks more than when he finds rest from toil and temptations.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:23
verses.text: As Hezekiah, when the Assyrians perished, praised the Lord, and, gave thanks, saying, 'The Lord is my salvation; and I will not cease to bless Thee with harp all the days of my life, before the house of the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:24
verses.text: ' And those valiant and blessed three who were tried in Babylon, Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah, when they were in safety and the fire became to them as dew, gave thanks, praising and 'saying words of glory to God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:25
verses.text: ' I too like them have written, my brethren, having these things in mind; for even in our time, God hath made possible those things which are impossible to men.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:26
verses.text: And those things which could not be accomplished by man, the Lord has shewn to be easy of accomplishment, by bringing us to you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:27
verses.text: For He does not give us as a prey to those who seek to swallow us up.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:28
verses.text: For it is not so much us, as the Church, and the faith and godliness which they planned to overwhelm with wickedness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:29
verses.text: But God, who is good, multiplied His loving-kindness towards us, not only when He granted the common salvation of us all through His Word, but now also, when enemies have persecuted us, and have sought to seize upon us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:30
verses.text: As the blessed Paul saith in a certain place, when describing the incomprehensible riches of Christ: 'But God, being rich in mercy, for the great love wherewith He loved us, even when we were dead in follies and sins, quickened us with Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:31
verses.text: ' For the might of man and of all creatures, is weak and poor; but the Might which is above man, and uncreated, is rich and incomprehensible, and has no beginning, but is eternal.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:32
verses.text: He does not then possess one method only of healing, but being rich, He works in divers manners for our salvation by means of His Word, Who is not restricted or hindered in His dealings towards us; but since He is rich and manifold, He varies Himself according to the individual capacity of each soul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:33
verses.text: For He is the Word and the Power and the Wisdom of God, as Solomon testifies concerning Wisdom, that 'being one, it can do all things, and remaining in itself, it maketh all things new; and passing upon holy souls, fashioneth the friends of God and the prophets.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:34
verses.text: ' To those then who have not yet attained to the perfect way He becomes like a sheep giving milk, and this was administered by Paul: 'I have fed you with milk, not with meat.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:35
verses.text: ' To those who have advanced beyond the full stature of childhood, but still are weak as regards perfection, He is their food, according to their capacity, being again administered by Paul, 'Let him that is weak eat herbs.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:36
verses.text: ' But as soon as ever a man begins to walk in the perfect way, he is no longer fed with the things before mentioned, but he has the Word for bread, and flesh for food, for it is written, 'Strong meat is for those who are of full age, for those who, by reason of their capacity, have their senses exercised.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:37
verses.text: ' And further, when the word is sown it does not yield a uniform produce of fruit in this human life, but one various and rich; for it bringeth forth, some an hundred, and some sixty, and some thirty, as the Saviour teaches—that Sower of grace, and Bestower of the Spirit.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:38
verses.text: And this is no doubtful matter, nor one that admits no confirmation; but it is in our power to behold the field which is sown by Him; for in the Church the word is manifold and the produce rich.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:39
verses.text: Not with virgins alone is such a field adorned; nor with monks alone, but also with honourable matrimony and the chastity of each one.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:40
verses.text: For in sowing, He did not compel the will beyond the power.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:41
verses.text: Nor is mercy confined to the perfect, but it is sent down also among those who occupy the middle and the third ranks, so that He might rescue all men generally to salvation.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:42
verses.text: To this intent He hath prepared many mansions with the Father, so that although the dwelling-place is various in proportion to the advance in moral attainment, yet all of us are within the wall, and all of us enter within the same fence, the adversary being cast out, and all his host expelled thence.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:43
verses.text: For apart from light there is darkness, and apart from blessing there is a curse, the devil also is apart from the saints, and sin far from virtue.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:44
verses.text: Therefore the Gospel rebukes Satan, saying, 'Get thee behind Me, Satan.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:45
verses.text: ' But us it calls to itself, saying, 'Enter ye in at the strait gate.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:46
verses.text: ' And again, 'Come, blessed of My Father, inherit the kingdom which is prepared for you.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:47
verses.text: ' So also the Spirit cried aforetime in the Psalms, saying, 'Enter into His gates with psalms.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:48
verses.text: ' For through virtue a man enters in unto God, as Moses did into the thick cloud where God was.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:49
verses.text: But through vice a man goes out from the presence of the Lord; as Cain when he had slain his brother, went out, as far as his will was concerned, from before the face of God; and the Psalmist enters, saying, 'And I will go in to the altar of God, even to the God that delighteth my youth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:50
verses.text: ' But of the devil the Scripture beareth witness, that the devil went out from before God, and smote Job with sore boils.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:51
verses.text: For this is the characteristic of those who go out from before God—to smite and to injure the men of God.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:52
verses.text: And this is the characteristic of those who fall away from the faith—to injure and persecute the faithful.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:53
verses.text: The saints on the other hand, take such to themselves and look upon them as friends; as also the blessed David, using openness of speech, says, 'Mine eyes are on the faithful of the earth, that they may dwell with me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:54
verses.text: ' But those that are weak in the faith, Paul urges that we should especially take to ourselves.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:55
verses.text: For virtue is philanthropic, just as in men of an opposite character, sin is misanthropic.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:56
verses.text: So Saul, being a sinner, persecuted David, whereas David, though he had a good opportunity, did not kill Saul.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:57
verses.text: Esau too persecuted Jacob, while Jacob overcame his wickedness by meekness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:58
verses.text: And those eleven sold Joseph, but Joseph, in his loving-kindness, had pity on them.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:59
verses.text: But what need we many words? Our Lord and Saviour, when He was persecuted by the Pharisees, wept for their destruction.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:60
verses.text: He was injured, but He threatened not; not when He was afflicted, not even when He was killed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:61
verses.text: But He grieved for those who dared to do such things.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:62
verses.text: He, the Saviour, suffered for man, but they despised and cast from them life, and light, and grace.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:63
verses.text: All these were theirs through that Saviour Who suffered in our stead.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:64
verses.text: And verily for their darkness and blindness, He wept.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:65
verses.text: For if they had understood the things which are written in the Psalms, they would not have been so vainly daring against the Saviour, the Spirit having said, 'Why do the heathen rage, and the people imagine a vain thing?' And if they had considered the prophecy of Moses, they would not have hanged Him Who was their Life.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:66
verses.text: And if they had examined with their understanding the things which were written, they would not have carefully fulfilled the prophecies which were against themselves, so as for their city to be now desolate, grace taken from them, and they themselves without the law, being no longer called children, but strangers.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:67
verses.text: For thus in the Psalms was it before declared, saying, 'The strange children have acted falsely by Me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:68
verses.text: ' And by Isaiah the prophet; 'I have begotten and brought up children, and they have rejected Me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:69
verses.text: ' And they are no longer named the people of God, and a holy nation, but rulers of Sodom, and people of Gomorrah; having exceeded in this even the iniquity of the Sodomites, as the prophet also saith, 'Sodom is justified before thee.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:70
verses.text: ' For the Sodomites raved against angels, but these against the Lord and God and King of all, and these dared to slay the Lord of angels, not knowing that Christ, who was slain by them, liveth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:71
verses.text: But those Jews who had conspired against the Lord died, having rejoiced a very little in these temporal things, and having fallen away from those which are eternal.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:72
verses.text: They were ignorant of this—that the immortal promise has not respect to temporal enjoyment, but to the hope of those things which are everlasting.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:73
verses.text: For through many tribulations, and labours, and sorrows, the saint enters into the kingdom of heaven; but when he arrives where sorrow, and distress, and sighing, shall flee away, he shall thenceforward enjoy rest; as Job, who, when tried here, was afterwards the familiar friend of the Lord.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:74
verses.text: But the lover of pleasures, rejoicing for a little while, afterwards passes a sorrowful life; like Esau, who had temporal food, but afterwards was condemned thereby.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:75
verses.text: We may take as a type of this distinction, the departure of the children of Israel and the Egyptians from Egypt.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:76
verses.text: For the Egyptians, rejoicing a little while in their injustice against Israel, when they went forth, were all drowned in the deep; but the people of God, being for a time smitten and injured, by the conduct of the taskmasters, when they came out of Egypt, passed through the sea unharmed, and walked in the wilderness as an inhabited place.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:77
verses.text: For although the place was unfrequented by man and desolate, yet, through the gracious gift of the law, and through converse with angels, it was no longer desert, but far more than an inhabited country.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:78
verses.text: As also Elisha, when he thought he was alone in the wilderness, was with companies of angels; so in this case, though the people were at first afflicted and in the wilderness, yet those who remained faithful afterwards entered the land of promise.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:79
verses.text: In like manner those who suffer temporal afflictions here, finally having endured, attain comfort, while those who here persecute are trodden under foot, and have no good end.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:80
verses.text: For even the rich man, as the Gospel affirms, having indulged in pleasure here for a little while, suffered hunger there, and having drunk largely here, he there thirsted exceedingly.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:81
verses.text: But Lazarus, after being afflicted in worldly things, found rest in heaven, and having hungered for bread ground from corn, he was there satisfied with that which is better than manna, even the Lord who came down and said, 'I am the bread which came down from heaven, and giveth life to mankind.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:83
verses.text: Oh! my dearly beloved, if we shall gain comfort from afflictions, if rest from labours, if health after sickness, if from death immortality, it is not right to be distressed by the temporal ills that lay hold on mankind.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:84
verses.text: It does not become us to be agitated because of the trials which befall us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:85
verses.text: It is not right to fear if the gang that contended with Christ, should conspire against godliness; but we should the more please God through these things, and should consider such matters as the probation and exercise of a virtuous life.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:86
verses.text: For how shall patience be looked for, if there be not previously labours and sorrows? Or how can fortitude be tested with no assault from enemies? Or how shall magnanimity be exhibited, unless after contumely and injustice? Or how can long-suffering be proved, unless there has first been the calumny of Antichrist? And, finally, how can a man behold virtue with his eyes, unless the iniquity of the very wicked has previously appeared? Thus even our Lord and Saviour Jesus Christ comes before us, when He would shew men how to suffer, Who when He was smitten bore it patiently, being reviled He reviled not again, when He suffered He threatened not, but He gave His back to the smiters, and His cheeks to buffetings, and turned not His face from spitting; and at last, was willingly led to death, that we might behold in Him the image of all that is virtuous and immortal, and that we, conducting ourselves after these examples, might truly tread on serpents and scorpions, and on all the power of the enemy.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:87
verses.text: Thus too Paul, while he conducted himself after the example of the Lord, exhorted us, saying, 'Be ye followers of me, as I also am of Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:88
verses.text: ' In this way he prevailed against all the divisions of the devil, writing, 'I am persuaded that neither death, nor life, nor angels, nor principalities, nor things present, nor things to come, nor powers, nor height, nor depth, nor any other creature, shall be able to separate us from the love of God which is in Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:89
verses.text: ' For the enemy draws near to us in afflictions, and trials, and labours, using every endeavour to ruin us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:90
verses.text: But the man who is in Christ, combating those things that are contrary, and opposing wrath by long-suffering, contumely by meekness, and vice by virtue, obtains the victory, and exclaims, 'I can do all things through Christ Who strengtheneth me;' and, 'In all these things we are conquerors through Christ Who loved us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:91
verses.text: ' This is the grace of the Lord, and these are the Lord's means of restoration for the children of men.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:92
verses.text: For He suffered to prepare freedom from suffering for those who suffer in Him, He descended that He might raise us up, He took on Him the trial of being born, that we might love Him Who is unbegotten, He went down to corruption, that corruption might put on immortality, He became weak for us, that we might rise with power, He descended to death, that He might bestow on us immortality, and give life to the dead.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:93
verses.text: Finally, He became man, that we who die as men might live again, and that death should no more reign over us; for the Apostolic word proclaims, 'Death shall not have the dominion over us.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:95
verses.text: Now because they did not thus consider these matters, the Ario-maniacs, being opponents of Christ, and heretics, smite Him who is their Helper with their tongue, and blaspheme Him who set [them] free, and hold all manner of different opinions against the Saviour.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:96
verses.text: Because of His coming down, which was on behalf of man, they have denied His essential Godhead; and seeing that He came forth from the Virgin, they doubt His being truly the Son of God, and considering Him as become incarnate in time, they deny His eternity; and, looking upon Him as having suffered for us, they do not believe in Him as the incorruptible Son from the incorruptible Father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:97
verses.text: And finally, because He endured for our sakes, they deny the things which concern His essential eternity; allowing the deed of the unthankful, these despise the Saviour, and offer Him insult instead of acknowledging His grace.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:98
verses.text: To them may these words justly be addressed: Oh! unthankful opponent of Christ, altogether wicked, and the slayer of his Lord, mentally blind, and a Jew in his mind, hadst thou understood the Scriptures, and listened to the saints, who said, 'Cause Thy face to shine, and we shall be saved;' or again, 'Send out Thy light and Thy truth;'—then wouldest thou have known that the Lord did not descend for His own sake, but for ours; and for this reason, thou wouldest the more have admired His loving kindness.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:99
verses.text: And hadst thou considered what the Father is, and what the Son, thou wouldest not have blasphemed the Son, as of a mutable nature.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:100
verses.text: And hadst thou understood His work of loving-kindness towards us, thou wouldest not have alienated the Son from the Father, nor have looked upon Him as a stranger, Who reconciled us to His Father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:101
verses.text: I know these [words] are grievous, not only to those who dispute with Christ, but also to the schismatics; for they are united together, as men of kindred feelings.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:102
verses.text: For they have learned to rend the seamless coat of God: they think it not strange to divide the indivisible Son from the Father.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:103
verses.text: I know indeed, that when these things are spoken, they will gnash their teeth upon us, with the devil who stirs them up, since they are troubled by the declaration of the true glory concerning the Redeemer.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:104
verses.text: But the Lord, Who always has scoffed at the devil, does the same even now, saying, 'I am in the Father, and the Father in Me.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:105
verses.text: ' This is the Lord, Who is manifested in the Father, and in Whom also the Father is manifested; Who, being truly the Son of the Father, at last became incarnate for our sakes, that He might offer Himself to the Father in our stead, and redeem us through His oblation and sacrifice.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:106
verses.text: This is He Who once brought the people of old time out of Egypt; but Who afterwards redeemed all of us, or rather the whole race of men, from death, and brought them up from the grave.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:107
verses.text: This is He Who in old time was sacrificed as a lamb, He being signified in the lamb; but Who afterwards was slain for us, for 'Christ our Passover is sacrificed.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:108
verses.text: ' This is He Who delivered us from the snare of the hunters, from the opponents of Christ, I say, and from the schismatics, and again rescued us His Church.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:109
verses.text: And because we were then victims of deceit, He has now delivered us by His own self.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:110
verses.text: What then is our duty, my brethren, for the sake of these things, but to praise and give thanks to God, the King of all? And let us first exclaim in the words of the Psalms, 'Blessed be the Lord, Who hath not given us over as a prey to their teeth.

verses.name: Athanasius: Festal Letters 8:111
verses.text: ' Let us keep the feast in that way which He hath dedicated for us unto salvation—the holy day Easter—so that we may celebrate the feast which is in heaven with the angels.
